# Summary of PuSh-Pull and DSGT

In the Push-Pull method, if we set graph $\mathcal{G}$ is connected and undirected, then $\mathcal{G}=\mathcal{G}_R=\mathcal{G}_C$,i.e.,$R=C:=W$. The algorithm \@ref(exm:pp) becomes the form of 
\begin{align}
X_{k+1} &= W(X_{k}-\boldsymbol\alpha Y_k),\\
Y_{k+1} &= WY_k+\nabla F(X_{k+1})-\nabla F(X_k)
(\#eq:pp)
\end{align}

If we further assume we only have noisy estimates of $\nabla F(X)$, i.e. $G(X,\boldsymbol\xi)$, we get DSGT \@ref(exm:dsgt).

In the proof of $\rho(A_{pp})<1$, the spectral radius of $A$ of the linear system of inequalities in the Push-Pull method, the authors use $1>(1-a_{22})\geq\frac{1-\sigma_R}{2}$,and $1>(1-a_{33})\geq\frac{1-\sigma_C}{2}$ to build a sufficient condition for $\hat\alpha$, which avoid discussing the sign of $c_i,i=1,2,3$ of $c_{3}-c_{2} \hat{\alpha}-c_{1} \hat{\alpha}^{2}$.

The idea of proving $\rho(A_{dsgt})<1$ may also be adopted here. 

\begin{align}

\det(I-A) &= (1-a_{11})\left[(1-a_{22})(1-a_{33})-a_{32}a_{23}\right] -\\
& a_{21}\left[a_{12}(1-a_{33})-a_{32}a_{13}\right] + \\
& a_{31}\left[a_{12}a_{23}-(1-a_{22})a_{13}\right]\\
\end{align}
